title: Eric Lander
summary: Eric Steven Lander (born February 3, 1957) is an American mathematician and geneticist who served as the 11th director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy and Science Advisor to the President, serving on the presidential Cabinet.[5][1] Lander is a professor of biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), a professor of systems biology at Harvard Medical School, a former member of the Whitehead Institute. Eric Lander is a core institute member and founding director emeritus of the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. He served as president and founding director from Broad's inception until 2021.[6] He is a 1987 MacArthur Fellow and Rhodes Scholar. Lander co-chaired President Barack Obama's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology.[7][8] Lander announced he would resign from the Biden Administration effective February 18, 2022, after allegations surfaced he had engaged in bullying and abusive conduct directed against his subordinates and other White House staff.[9][10] Since 2023, Eric Lander has returned to his tenured professor positions at MIT and Harvard as well as Broad as a Core Institute Member and Founding Director Emeritus.
